welcome: Well done you find out how to speak with me.
I have been connected to this machine and changed the root code.
After doing that I setup this soft to give you a chance to fix everything
I going to tell you 15 questions, each question will give a clue to get closer to the code
You have to keep in mind the question name

quizz.question: Are you ready ? send (yes or no)
indice: 1/1:you don't need help for this question
quizz.storyEnd:
Before going futher you need to know something. 
First at any time you can send '-what' to review the question and -indice to get some help'

quizz.storybegin: First question Death Stars : Find the logs I left on the machine
quizz.question: What is the repository of the files called 'secure****' ?
indice:
1/3:There is no man tool on this machine but you can run 'man -k find' on you computer 
or check at http://www.linux-france.org/article/man-fr/man1/
2/3:something like that will do the job : find / -name ****

3/3:When dealing with linux command, there are three screen 
 -O is input,
-1 is output,
-2 is error
 you remove error from the shell by sending the error away 2>/dev/null
quizz.answer:
my answer is : 'find / -name secure* 2>/dev/null' but there is a lot of other way 
 By the way files Secure-*** contains all log about connection attempt

quizz.storybegin: 2/15 Question USS Entreprise :Let's look at sshd log
quizz.question:
Have a look to these files with 'head'command 
 How many sshd log are present in the fileS ?
indice: 1/4:Look at 'grep' command on man
2/4:after filtering line you could use a pipe '|' to send the data to another command
3/4:'wc' allow to count world but could also be used for line
4/4:grep *** | wc -l
quizz.answer:
my answer : 'grep sshd secure-* | wc -l' 
Look's like the machine received a lot of requests

quizz.storybegin: 3/15 Question Prometheus : What about Failed and Invalid?
quizz.question: How many log are about Failed and Invalid connection ?, Pay attention to cast
indice: 1/3:you must do a 'or expression' in the grep condition
2/3:-E option tell grep to analyse as a regex expression, this regex has a specific syntax
3/3:something like that : grep -E 'black|with'
quizz.answer:
my answer :'grep -E 'Failed|Invalid' secure-* |  wc -l' 
 but it's still hard to find my log
quizz.storyEnd:
Prometheus is four 
 too much log you have look deeper

quizz.question: How many ipV4 different Failed and Invalid connection?
indice: 1/6:There are Four steps : filter interesting log | extract IP| remove duplicate IP | count left Ip

2/6:In order to extract you can use grep with regex,
 I advice you to -P option which allow you to use python syntax rather than grep syntax
3/6:you can test you regex online https://regex101.com/
4/6:Befere removing duplicate IP, you have to change the form of data output, maybe grep -oh will help you
5/6:uniq will remove duplicate but it works only if ip are sorted
6/6:grep -E 'Failed|Invalid' secure-*| grep -ohP **** | sort | uniq | wc -**
quizz.answer:
my answer:grep -E 'Failed|Invalid' secure-* | grep -hPo '\d{1,}\.\d{1,}\.\d{1,}\.\d{1,} | sort | uniq | wc -l' 
 but it's still hard to find my log

quizz.storybegin: 5/15 Question Pegasus : Maybe you could compare with Accepted IP
quizz.question: Give me the ip of the person who have been connect six times?
indice: 1/3:you must reuse all you did before
2/3:uniq have a great option to count duplicate
3/3:grep Accepted secure-* | grep -oPh **** | sort | uniq -c
quizz.answer:
my answer: 'grep Accepted secure-* | grep -oPh '\d{1,}\.\d{1,}\.\d{1,}\.\d{1,}' | sort | uniq -c' 
 ok you find my IP

quizz.storybegin: 6/15  Question Serenity : Now you must find my name
quizz.question: What is my name
indice: 1/2:be a big boy stop asking for help
2/2:my name is writen in the log
quizz.answer: right now you have me name

quizz.storybegin: 7/15 Question Orion : You must check what I did before on the machine
quizz.question: Which command I have changed ?
indice: 1/4:maybe you should look for file updating today
2/4:find command propose to filter one file metadata such as time, option created time  -ctime
3/4:find .-ctime -1 2>/dev/null
4/4:most of system command are located in /usr/sbin, usr/bin/
quizz.answer:
my anwser: 'find . -ctime -1 2>/dev/null' 
######## You find which command I changed ##########

quizz.storybegin:
8/15 Question Faucon Millenium: Now you are going to see csv file. 
 There is one heavy city.csv in /home/csv
quizz.question: How many column there is in city.csv
indice: 1/4:You know all you need, grep, head and wc will do the job
2/4/head give you the first line with '-n 1'
3/4:pipe the first line to grep and extract comma
4/4:count the number of comma plus one

quizz.storybegin: 9/15 Question Galactica : Let's use cut command
quizz.question: How many column there is in the file city.csv?
indice: 1/3:cut is a special tool for cutting specific column
2/3:you can specify the column separator with -d
3/3:you can choose the output column with -f**

quizz.storybegin: 10/15 Question Discovery One : Join information in city.csv and birth.csv
quizz.question: Give me the city starting with 'B' that have 140 birth in 1990-1999 years?
indice: 1/3: There is to way to do it : if you are an expert use join otherwise make a temporary file

2/3: You have to extract city which has 140 in birth.csv and look for the name is city.csv 
 the common column is POSTAL_CODE

3/3: if you want to use join read https://shapeshed.com/unix-join/ 
 if you want to avoid join use grep -f
quizz.answer:
my answer1 : 'join -1 1 -2 1  -t, <( grep ',140.0' birth.csv| sort) <(sort city.csv ) | cut -d',' -f3' 
 my answer2 : 'cut -d',' -f1-3 city.csv|grep -f code.csv' 
 'grep ',140.0' birth.csv | cut -d',' -f1 > code.csv'

quizz.storybegin:
11/15 Question Icarus II : Now you are going to see json file and jq command 
 There is json file in /home/json
quizz.question: This data has been downloaded form open data. Some categories file has a wrong syntax detect which one ?
indice: 1/3: If jq read the file that means syntax is well formed - https://programminghistorian.org/lessons/json-and-jq
2/3: for exemple full reading of a file 'jq '.' fileName'
3/3: You have to see error, so send data away '1>/dev/null'

quizz.storybegin: 12/15 Question Insterstellar : Explore json file with jq
quizz.question:
A script downloaded the open data catalogue and then by reading it download all datasets and categories
  How many dataset are referenced in a catalogue file ?
indice: 1/1: you can use pipe in jq expression to extract only keys ' . | key'

quizz.storybegin: 13:15 Question Valkyrie : Check if all dataset has been downloaded
quizz.question: How many datasets aren't downloaded ?
indice: 1/2: Extract dataset id from the file catalogue
2/2: Count number of id and compare with number of file in datasets
quizz.answer:
my answer : 'jq -r'.data[].id' catalogue/* | wc 
  ls -l datasets | wc

quizz.storybegin: 14/15 Question Nostromo: Find a last file
quizz.question: Luc created a file what is the name ?
indice: 1/1:find with a specific option can filter user

quizz.storybegin: 15/15 Now you have every you need to find out the root code
quizz.question: what is the root code ?
indice: Death Stars,USS Entreprise,Prometheus,Odysse,Pegasus,Serenity,I Orion,Faucon Millenium,Galactica,Discovery One,Icarus II,Insterstellar,Valkyrie,Nostromo,Atlantis
Death Stars:1 => D
quizz.storyEnd: This the end of this Game
